awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Towards Efficient and Scalable Crowdsourced Vulnerability-Discovery using Bug-Bounty Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
Many organizations and companies have recently chosen to use so-called bug-bounty programs, which allow outside security experts to evaluate the security of an organization's products and services and to report security vulnerabilities in exchange for rewards. Bug-bounty programs provide unique benefits by allowing organizations to publicly signal their commitment to security and to harness the diverse expertise of thousands of security experts in an affordable way. Despite their rapidly growing popularity, bug-bounty programs are not well understood and can be mismanaged. As a result, bug bounty programs can waste substantial resources and they rarely live up to their potential to improve cybersecurity. This project will significantly improve the efficiency of bug-bounty programs by collecting and publishing comprehensive datasets on the bug-bounty ecosystem, by establishing a sound theory of bug-bounty programs, and by providing practical recommendations for organizations and regulators. The project will directly benefit organizations and companies by enabling them to manage bug-bounty programs more efficiently, which will allow them to eliminate security vulnerabilities at a lower cost, and it will also benefit users by improving the security of products and services.

The project will have four research thrusts. The first thrust will build a dataset that captures the entire bug-bounty ecosystem by collecting activity data and rule descriptions from public bug-bounty programs, conducting interviews and focus-group studies with experts who regularly participate in programs, collecting social-media posts, and incorporating existing datasets, such as vulnerability databases. The second thrust will analyze this dataset to understand the ecosystem and its actors' incentives and actions, and to characterize processes, such as discovering and reporting vulnerabilities and rewarding reports. To code textual data, the project will first develop a terminology and taxonomy of bug-bounty related concepts. Driven by the results of the data analysis, the third thrust will develop a formal model of the bug-bounty ecosystem, which will incorporate technological processes as well as behavioral and economic incentives. To capture all aspects of such a complex ecosystem, the project will employ models and techniques from multiple disciplines and areas, including economics and cybersecurity. Building on this model, the fourth thrust will propose and evaluate novel approaches for improving the efficiency and scalability of bug-bounty programs. The project will consider policies for individual bug-bounty programs, such as rules for rewarding vulnerability reports, as well as mechanisms for regulating bug-bounty programs and for instigating coordination between them. The research project will also involve graduate students from underrepresented groups, who will have an excellent opportunity to engage in interdisciplinary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to improve the efficiency of bug-bounty programs. Despite their rapidly growing popularity, bug-bounty programs are not well understood and can easily be mismanaged, wasting substantial resources and failing to live up to their true potential to strengthen cybersecurity. To enable better management of bug-bounty programs, this project built and studied comprehensive datasets on the bug-bounty ecosystem, and provided practical guidance and policies for managing bug-bounty programs.

To build comprehensive datasets, the project conducted qualitative and quantitative surveys and interviews with security experts who work on bug-bounty programs, providing novel insights into their motivations and choices, the challenges that they face, and the benefits that they perceive. These insights enable identifying key issues and opportunities for improvement in the bug-bounty ecosystem. To capture the organizations’ perspective as well, the project complemented the survey and interview results by collecting vulnerability-management data from widely-used software products, including vulnerability reports, security notices, and examples of exploited vulnerabilities. By studying vulnerability-management data, the project identified opportunities for improving the management of bug bounties, and it made strides in quantifying the benefits of vulnerability discovery, a fundamental problem in the economics of security. Finally, to understand the threat actors’ perspective, the project conducted a survey of the academic literature and industry reports on how adversaries perform reconnaissance and identify vulnerabilities, establishing a rigorous taxonomy that enables more realistic modeling of adversaries. In addition to providing recommendations based on data analysis, the project also introduced novel computational approaches for cybersecurity decision support.

The findings of this project will directly benefit members of the bug-bounty ecosystem, including security experts, organizations that sponsor bug-bounty programs, and bug-bounty platforms. The project provides practitioners with comprehensive bug-bounty datasets, analysis results that identify inefficiencies and issues in bug-bounty programs, and practical recommendations for improving efficiency. These results will be immediately useful to organizations and platforms, enabling them to improve their programs. Through reducing wasted effort, increasing participation, etc., these improvements will lower the costs and increase the productivity of crowdsourced vulnerability discovery. The publicly available resources will be especially beneficial to small businesses that are new to bug bounty and lack experience and expertise in managing them. Further, improvements in the ecosystem will also benefit security experts who participate in bug bounty since their efforts and talents will be utilized better and may be rewarded more.

The improvement of bug-bounty programs will have a positive spillover effect for users, i.e., for individuals and companies who use software products or services that are within the scope of improved programs. In particular, more secure software products and services may result in fewer cyber-incidents that could negatively impact users, while reduced security costs may lead to lower product prices or service fees. The project has also involved graduate students from traditionally underrepresented groups in computer-science research.
